title: 113_hr4756
content: The Act is titled the "Bullying Redress and Verified Enforcement Act" or the "BRAVE Act." It amends Title IX of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include reporting requirements on bullying. The "BRAVE Act" amends Title IX to include reporting requirements on bullying, mandating employees to report acts of bullying within 7 business days. Reported details must include the acts of bullying, any reference to protected characteristics, and the response by the educational agency. The "BRAVE Act" amends Title IX to include reporting requirements on bullying, mandating employees to report acts of bullying within 7 business days. A local educational agency must designate an individual to receive reports of bullying. An exception is made for employees who are informed of bullying by a student but the student requests that the bullying not be reported. The "BRAVE Act" requires employees to report bullying within 7 days. A designated individual at the local educational agency receives reports of bullying and informs all employees without disclosing student's personal information. If a student requests that bullying not be reported, the employee is not obligated to report it. The designated individual at the local educational agency informs employees of reported bullying acts and their responses. Quarterly reports summarizing reported bullying and responses by employees are made publicly available to students and parents. The local educational agency and parents receive quarterly reports summarizing reported bullying incidents and employee responses, excluding any student's personal information. The public is informed of the right to file a complaint. Each local educational agency must annually review bullying policies for schools they serve. As a condition of receiving funds, agencies must certify compliance with federal regulations. Local educational agencies must annually certify compliance with federal regulations and submit quarterly reports to receive funds under this Act. The Office of Civil Rights establishes a procedure for receiving complaints from students or parents. The Assistant Secretary of the Office of Civil Rights for the Department of Education establishes a procedure for receiving complaints regarding non-compliance with federal regulations by local educational agencies. The Assistant Secretary of the Office of Civil Rights for the Department of Education investigates complaints of non-compliance by local educational agencies and can withhold funds, issue a cease and desist order, or enter into a compliance agreement. The Assistant Secretary of the Office of Civil Rights can take actions to compel compliance from local educational agencies, such as issuing a cease and desist order or entering into a compliance agreement. Information about complaints must be made public on the Department of Education's website within 60 days. The Assistant Secretary must make information about complaints public on the Department of Education's website within 60 days, including details about the complaint and excluding any personally identifiable information. The term 'bullying' is defined as severe, pervasive, or persistent electronic, written, verbal behavior. The term 'bullying' is defined as any severe, pervasive, or persistent electronic, written, verbal, or physical act by one student or a group of students towards another student causing harm or concern for their well-being. It also includes actions that make the targeted student withdraw from school activities. The term 'bullying' is defined as any severe, pervasive, or persistent act causing harm or concern for a student's well-being, leading them to withdraw from school activities. Protected characteristics include race, color, sex, religion, national origin, disability, gender, gender identity, and sexual orientation.
